title: How We Got Here #10 The Techno-Tween Age: The Late 1990s (The Internet, Teen Music &  Movies, Raves)
description:
Welcome to the Fin De Siécle, the Late 1990's, the End of the Century, the End of the Millennium, the End of an Era; what I am calling the Techno-Tween Age. This is when the Internet suddenly caught on globally. This when when culture ceased being about adulthood and maturity ceased being a public value. This is when Teens and Tweens suddenly defined the culture, all the while not realizing that their desires we're being manufactured for them. Being cool and listening to rock music was no longer a sign of rebellion but an aspect of containment. This when Oklahoma blew up, video games and anime came to predominate, people were hysterical about the Y2K glitch and Columbine High School became a symbol of a greater youth disruption. Names like Steve Jobs, Bill Gates, Noam Chomsky, Marilyn Manson, Eminem, the Insane Clown Posse defined the times. We were rushing towards the end of the millennium with abandon and glee all the while expecting Armageddon. (Not knowing that what we expected had to wait 20 years to get here.) 

It was the Time of Your Life. Oh wait that was actually a song by Green Day called Good Riddance filled with dismissive lyrics that teachers somehow thought would make great graduation slideshow music. Ah the Late Nineties...

Since this is another long chapter in our historical saga here are some timestamps for the different sections. You can take as much or little as you want when you want it.

02:30 The Pattern In Modern Arts
15:45 The End Of Rock As Rebellion
24:20 Music For Teens & Tweens
53:30 A New Vision Of Youth
01:10:20 Welcome To The Internet
01:25:25 Technological Entertainments
01:30:40 Raving Electronica
01:56:00 Fin De Siécle
02:36:00 Coda

That's why their music is listed below. Ah the sweet sound of rebellion.
